content.text: This is a HE WSI of a CRC case, consisting of lymph nodes or primary tumor section. What is your initial impression of this image?

The thumbnail displays multiple fragments of tissue. There are approximately 10 ovoid, basophilic (purple) structures that are consistent in appearance with lymph nodes. These are embedded in lighter-staining fibro-adipose tissue. The nodes vary in size. The overall impression is a lymph node dissection specimen submitted for staging of a colorectal cancer.
Are there any places you want to look into further? Give me reasons why you want to look into each region.

As a pathologist, my task is to systematically evaluate every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. The selected area corresponds to the first lymph node from the top left. I would start my examination here and proceed to review all other nodes on the slide to determine the final N stage. I am looking for atypical epithelial cells, either singly, in clusters, or forming glands, which would indicate metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am systematically examining all potential lymph nodes on the slide. The area indicated by the green box contains one of the smaller lymphoid structures, located in the upper-left quadrant of the tissue. It is the third lymph node from the top. It's essential to scrutinize every single lymph node, regardless of its size, because even small nodes can harbor metastatic deposits. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the primary task for this slide is to determine the N stage by identifying any lymph nodes containing metastatic cancer. This requires a systematic, high-power examination of every single lymph node present. The selected area corresponds to the second lymph node from the top. I would zoom into this area as part of that routine systematic review. Additionally, this particular node has a slightly less defined border and a more mottled appearance compared to some of the others, which could indicate either benign reactive changes (like prominent germinal centers) or metastatic infiltration, thus requiring closer inspection. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into this area as part of a systematic examination of all the lymph nodes present. The selected area is the periphery of one of the larger lymph nodes, specifically targeting the subcapsular sinus. Metastatic cells that travel through lymphatic vessels typically first lodge and grow in this subcapsular sinus. Therefore, this is the highest-yield area to screen for early metastatic deposits. At low power, there might be a subtle hint of architectural disruption or cellular crowding in this region, prompting a closer look. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my task is to systematically examine every lymph node on the slide to look for evidence of metastasis. I am zooming into this specific lymph node (one of the central ones) to assess its architecture and cellular composition at high magnification. At low power, it's difficult to distinguish a reactive lymph node from one with a subtle metastatic deposit. Therefore, a high-power view is essential to identify any atypical, non-lymphoid cells (i.e., tumor cells) that would indicate a positive lymph node. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to systematically examine every lymph node to check for the presence of metastatic cancer cells. I would methodically move from one node to another. The green box highlights the lymph node located in the lower-left portion of the slide. I am zooming into this specific node as part of my routine, comprehensive examination to assess its architecture, including the capsule, cortex, medulla, and sinuses, at a higher magnification to look for any atypical epithelial cells, either in clusters, glands, or as single cells, which would indicate metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am starting a systematic examination of all the lymph nodes present on the slide. The selected area is the lymph node located in the bottom-left corner of the slide. I am zooming in to assess its architecture at higher magnification, specifically looking at the subcapsular sinus and the parenchyma for any evidence of atypical cells or glandular structures that would indicate metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I would examine every lymph node on the slide to search for metastasis. The zoomed-in area focuses on one of these lymph nodes (the third one from the top, in the center). This is part of a systematic, comprehensive review. This specific node might have been chosen as the next in a sequence of examination, or perhaps a subtle irregularity in its shape or color at low power prompted a closer look. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary goal here is to screen every lymph node for evidence of metastasis. I would systematically examine each node on the slide. The selected area is the third lymph node from the top, centrally located. At low power, its architecture appears somewhat busy and mottled, which could represent reactive changes or, more importantly, infiltration by tumor cells. Therefore, I am zooming in to assess the cellular composition and architecture at higher magnification to rule in or out the presence of metastatic carcinoma. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, I must systematically examine every lymph node to screen for metastatic cancer. The green box is placed on the periphery of one of the lymph nodes. I would zoom into this area to closely inspect the interface between the lymph node parenchyma, its capsule, and the surrounding perinodal fat. This is a critical region to evaluate because metastatic tumor cells often first deposit in the subcapsular sinus. I also need to assess for extranodal extension, which is when the tumor breaks through the capsule into the adjacent fat, a key prognostic factor. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, my primary task here is to identify any lymph nodes positive for metastatic cancer. This requires a systematic, high-power examination of every lymph node submitted. The zoom into this area, which is on the 6th lymph node from the top in a clockwise review, is a routine step to carefully inspect the lymphoid architecture and cellular composition for any signs of non-native, malignant epithelial cells (adenocarcinoma) that would indicate metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. As a pathologist, the primary task for lymph node sections in a colorectal cancer case is to meticulously search for metastatic tumor cells. Each lymph node must be examined systematically at higher magnification. I am zooming into this specific area because it is one of the lymph nodes (located in the middle-right part of the slide) that needs to be assessed. The goal is to carefully inspect the subcapsular sinus, cortical, and medullary regions for any non-native cells, such as atypical epithelial glands or cell clusters, which would indicate metastasis. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. I am zooming into the periphery of the lymph node located in the lower right portion of the image. When assessing lymph nodes for metastasis in colorectal cancer, it is crucial to meticulously examine the subcapsular sinus, which is the area just beneath the outer capsule of the node. This is often the first site where metastatic tumor cells deposit after arriving via lymphatic vessels. By zooming into this interface between the lymphoid tissue and the surrounding perinodal fat, I am looking for any atypical epithelial cells, abnormal glandular structures, or small clusters of tumor cells that would signify metastasis, including micrometastasis or extranodal extension. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found]. The green box is placed in an area of adipose tissue, away from the main bodies of the well-defined lymph nodes. I would zoom into this specific area because I am systematically scanning the fat for any abnormalities between the obvious lymph nodes. My primary concern would be to look for small, inconspicuous lymph nodes, or more importantly, for 'tumor deposits' (also known as satellite nodules). These are discrete foci of cancer in the pericolic fat, separate from the primary tumor, without evidence of residual lymph node tissue. Identifying them is critical for accurate cancer staging. The low-power view shows some subtle cellularity in this fatty region that warrants high-power examination. I want to zoom into [coordinates not found].
This is ROI 1 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a cross-section of a lymph node. The overall architecture is preserved, with identifiable lymphoid follicles, some of which contain paler-staining germinal centers. The cellular population consists predominantly of lymphocytes. There are no definitive clusters of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or necrosis to suggest metastatic carcinoma. My impression is that this is a reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 2 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, I see a small aggregate of lymphoid tissue, consistent with a small, benign (reactive) lymph node. The cellular population consists of mature lymphocytes. Adjacent to the lymphoid tissue, there are blood vessels (an arteriole and a venule) and surrounding mature adipose tissue. I do not see any atypical cells, malignant glands, or other features of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression is that this is a negative lymph node (no evidence of metastasis).
This is ROI 3 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a portion of a lymph node adjacent to mature adipose tissue. The lymph node architecture appears preserved, showing a dense infiltrate of lymphocytes. There are several lymphoid follicles with prominent, pale-staining germinal centers, which are characteristic of reactive follicular hyperplasia. I do not see any distinct clusters of atypical, large epithelial cells with irregular nuclei or glandular formation that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. Therefore, my impression of this specific area is a reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 4 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I can see the fibrous capsule of the lymph node at the top, with adjacent adipose tissue. Directly beneath the capsule is a dense and monotonous population of small, dark lymphocytes, which constitute the normal parenchyma of the lymph node. The subcapsular sinus, the space just under the capsule, appears to be expanded and filled with cells. However, these cells are predominantly small lymphocytes, similar to the surrounding cortex, and some slightly larger cells with more cytoplasm, consistent with sinus histiocytes. I do not see definitive features of metastatic adenocarcinoma, such as large atypical cells, glandular formation, or significant nuclear pleomorphism. My impression of this specific field is that it shows reactive changes (sinus histiocytosis) rather than metastatic carcinoma. I would proceed to examine the rest of this lymph node and all other nodes thoroughly to confirm this finding.
This is ROI 5 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a dense and diffuse population of small, round, dark-staining cells with scant cytoplasm, which are characteristic of lymphocytes. The normal lymph node architecture appears to be largely intact, although perhaps with some reactive changes. I do not see any definite nests of atypical epithelial cells, glandular structures, or large pleomorphic cells that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The white, clear spaces appear to be processing artifacts or possibly dilated sinuses. My impression of this specific field of view is that it shows benign lymphoid tissue, and there is no evidence of metastasis in this area.
This is ROI 6 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-magnification view, I see a portion of a lymph node adjacent to perinodal adipose tissue and fibrous stroma. The lymph node tissue is composed of a dense, diffuse population of lymphocytes. I do not see any definite atypical glandular structures, nests of malignant epithelial cells, or extensive necrosis that would suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. The interface between the lymphoid tissue and the surrounding fat appears relatively well-defined, although some lymphocytes are present in the perinodal tissue, which can be a reactive feature. My impression of this specific field of view is that it shows a reactive lymph node with no evidence of metastasis. I would still need to pan across the entire node and examine all other lymph nodes on the slide to make a final diagnosis.
This is ROI 7 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this high-power view, the top portion of the image shows the dense lymphoid tissue of the lymph node. Below this, there is a fibrous capsule. Most importantly, at the very bottom, outside the main lymphoid aggregate and within the pericapsular adipose tissue, there are clear, back-to-back, atypical glandular structures. These glands are composed of malignant-appearing columnar cells with hyperchromatic, elongated nuclei, consistent with metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression is that this is a positive lymph node with metastatic adenocarcinoma present in the pericapsular soft tissue, which would be classified as extranodal extension.
This is ROI 8 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a high-power image of a lymph node. I can identify the fibrous capsule at the top, with adjacent mature adipose tissue. The node itself is densely cellular, composed predominantly of a monotonous population of small, dark lymphocytes. The architecture appears preserved with evidence of lymphoid follicles. There are no definitive nests of atypical epithelial cells, abnormal glandular structures, or extensive pools of mucin that would suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field of view is that it shows a reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 9 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a dense, diffuse infiltrate of lymphoid cells, which are small cells with dark, round nuclei and scant cytoplasm. The normal lymph node architecture, such as distinct germinal centers and sinuses, is partially effaced. However, I do not see the classic features of metastatic colorectal adenocarcinoma, such as back-to-back glands, large atypical epithelial cells with eosinophilic cytoplasm, or significant necrosis. The impression is that of a reactive lymph node, possibly showing follicular hyperplasia or sinus histiocytosis, rather than a lymph node positive for metastasis. Based on this field of view, this lymph node appears negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 10 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view displays the edge of a lymph node. The lower two-thirds of the image show dense lymphoid tissue, composed mainly of small, dark lymphocytes. The upper part shows perinodal adipose tissue (fat). A thin fibrous capsule separates the lymphoid tissue from the fat. I am looking for atypical cells, such as large epithelial cells forming glands or clusters, which would indicate metastatic adenocarcinoma. In this specific field of view, I do not see any convincing evidence of metastasis. The lymphoid tissue appears to be intact, and there are no tumor cells in the subcapsular sinus or invading the surrounding fat. My impression for this specific area is a benign/reactive lymph node, negative for malignancy.
This is ROI 11 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows a dense, polymorphous population of lymphocytes, characteristic of lymphoid tissue. I can identify small, mature lymphocytes, some slightly larger transformed lymphocytes, and small blood vessels. There are no definitive clusters of atypical, large epithelial cells with vesicular nuclei and prominent nucleoli that would be indicative of metastatic adenocarcinoma. The impression of this specific field of view is that of a reactive lymph node, showing sinus histiocytosis and follicular hyperplasia, but no evidence of malignancy.
This is ROI 12 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

In this zoomed-in area, I see a dense and polymorphous population of lymphoid cells. The cells are predominantly small lymphocytes with dark, round nuclei and scant cytoplasm. There are also scattered larger lymphoid cells (centroblasts/immunoblasts) and tangible body macrophages, which are characteristic features of a reactive germinal center. I do not see any atypical epithelial cells, glandular formations, or mucin pools. The overall architecture is preserved. My impression is that this is a benign, reactive lymph node, negative for metastatic carcinoma.
This is ROI 13 and its 40x cyto pattern. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view shows the capsule and subcapsular region of the lymph node. On the right, there is a dense, diffuse infiltrate of lymphoid cells, which are predominantly small, mature lymphocytes. On the left, there is perinodal fibro-adipose tissue containing several small blood vessels and adipocytes (fat cells). The capsule of the lymph node appears intact at this location. I do not see any definitive nests of malignant cells, atypical glands, or desmoplastic stromal reaction to suggest metastatic adenocarcinoma. My impression of this specific field of view is that it is a benign/reactive lymph node, but the entire periphery of this node and all other nodes on the slide must be thoroughly examined to confirm this finding.
This is ROI 14. What do you observe when you zoom in?

The zoomed-in view confirms the presence of mature adipose tissue, which constitutes the bulk of the field. However, at the upper left and upper right edges of this field, there are small, fragmented clusters of cellular tissue. The fragment on the left is particularly notable, showing a dense collection of cells with some pink, eosinophilic material. This is not normal tissue. My impression is that this is a suspicious finding. It could represent a small tumor deposit, a fragment of a lymph node that has been mostly replaced by tumor, or a focus of intense inflammation. Further magnification is required to examine the cytology of these cells to determine if they are malignant epithelial cells, which would confirm a tumor deposit, or purely inflammatory cells.
